bibl.title: Chin Hing v. United States of America. Motion
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: In the United States District Court, in and for the Western District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the Matter of the Application of Ching Hing, for a Writ of Habeas Corpus } No. 2857 Motion

Comes now John J. Sullivan, as attorney for petitioner Ching Hing, and respectfully prsents to this Hon. Court; that a petition was presented to this Hon. Court in the month of October, 1914, praying that a Writ of Habeas Corpus, be issued alleging that petitioner was confined and imprisoned and restrained of his liberty and that said restraint was illegal, and thereupon set out facts in said petition, to bear out his said statements, adn that said matter coming on for hearing on the 16th day of Octobfer, 1914, at which time a continuance was granted by this Hon. Court through Judge Neterer, ordering a commission to issue to Thomas G. Lewis, of Washington D.C., authorizing him to take the depostition of Lewis F. Post, and Corry M. Stadden, both of Washington, D.C. That said Lewis F. Post refuses to answer the said interrogaories, wehereupon an order was directed by the District Court, in and for the District of Columbnia, commanding Lewis F. Post to show cause why he should not answer the said interrogatories; that this matter is now pending, and that petitioner can not present his case in proper form until this matter is determined, and whereupon a bond in the sum of Fifteen Hundred (1500) Dollars, to await any Judgment or Order of this Court upon and in relation to said application for Writ of Habeas Corpus, now pending in this Court. This motion is based upon the facts hereinabove presented to this Court, and by the records and files in this Court.
State of Washington County of King } ss

John J. Sullivan, being first duly sworn, on oath deposes and says: That he is the Attorney for the Petitioner Ching Hing; that he has read the foregoing Motion, and believes the dame to be true and meritorious in law.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 2 day of March, 1915.
div1.ab: Adam Beeler Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
